inference:
Since $ABCD$ and $BEFG$ are squares, $BC=CD=DA=AB=BE=EF=FG=GB$. Also, triangle $BCE$ is equilateral, so $BC=CE=EB$. Thus, $BC=CD=DA=AB=BE=EF=FG=GB=CE$.
In square $ABCD$, $\angle BCD=90^\circ$. In equilateral triangle $BCE$, $\angle CBE = \angle BCE = \angle BEC = 60^\circ$.
$\angle BCE = 60^\circ$. Since $BC = CD$, $\triangle BCD$ is an isosceles triangle. $\angle CBD = \angle CDB = \frac{180^\circ - 90^\circ}{2} = 45^\circ$.
Since $BC=CE$, we know that $\angle CBE = 60^\circ$ and $\angle BCE = 60^\circ$. Also, $\angle BCD = 90^\circ$. Then $\angle DCE = \angle BCD - \angle BCE = 90^\circ - 60^\circ = 30^\circ$.
Since $BEFG$ is a square, $\angle EBG=90^\circ$. Since $\triangle BCE$ is equilateral, $BC=BE$. Since $BC=CD=DA=AB=BE=EF=FG=GB=CE$, we have $BE=BC$, so $BE=BC=CE$. In square $BEFG$, $\angle EBG = 90^\circ$. Since $BE = BC$, $\triangle CBE$ is equilateral. Also, $\angle CBE = 60^\circ$. Since $\angle CBE = 60^\circ$, we have $\angle BCE = 60^\circ$. In $\triangle BCE$, $\angle BCE = 60^\circ$, $\angle CBE = 60^\circ$, and $\angle BEC = 60^\circ$.
$\angle GCE = \angle GCB + \angle BCE$.
$\angle GCB = \angle BCD - \angle BCE = 90^\circ - 60^\circ = 30^\circ$. In square $BEFG$, $\angle EFG = 90^\circ$. Also $\angle EBC = 60^\circ$ and $\angle GBC = 90^\circ - 60^\circ = 30^\circ$.
Since $\angle BCE = 60^\circ$ and $\angle BCD = 90^\circ$, we have $\angle DCE = 90^\circ - 60^\circ = 30^\circ$. In square $BEFG$, we have $FG=FE$ and $\angle FGE = 90^\circ$.
Since $\angle BCD=90^{\circ}$ and $\angle BCE=60^{\circ}$, then $\angle DCE=90^{\circ}-60^{\circ}=30^{\circ}$.
$CE$ is a side of the equilateral triangle. Since $BC=CE$, $\triangle BCE$ is isosceles.
$\angle GCE = \angle GCB + \angle BCE$. $\angle GCB = \angle BCG = 90^\circ - 60^\circ = 30^\circ$. Thus, $\angle GCE = 30^\circ + 60^\circ = 90^\circ$.
$\angle GCE = 30^{\circ} + 60^{\circ} = 90^{\circ}$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{15}$
